channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Papua New Guinea’s workers abroad are an untapped resource
item.description: A diaspora syndicate fund could bridge the financing gap that leaves small enterprises starved of capital.

item.title: The G20 faces a test of meaning as major powers stay away
item.description: Trump’s attacks and some big absences steal the spotlight from what would be South Africa’s moment.

item.title: Australia’s Indian Ocean Territories matter again in the digital age
item.description: In a sign that geography is destiny, isolated islands look set to soon be essential nodes for the world’s data.

item.title: China-Japan Rift Deepens Over Taiwan
item.description: The new Japanese prime minister is unlikely to back down from recent comments.

item.title: The loneliness of America’s model ally
item.description: Donald Trump has no desire to play global cop. That is tough on Denmark, a loyal sheriff’s deputy

item.title: Why crypto’s spectacular market success is going sour
item.description: The industry got everything it wanted. Now it’s sinking

item.title: Crypto got everything it wanted. Now it’s sinking
item.description: The slump could ripple across financial markets

item.title: How One Vaccine Could Help Fight Drug-Resistant Infections
item.description: A cheap and practical intervention, given at birth, could save lives in conflict zones and beyond.

item.title: Why Is Washington Acting Like a Revisionist Power?
item.description: The U.S. made a global order that it’s now obsessed with overthrowing.

item.title: Trump, Mohammed bin Salman Dismiss Khashoggi Questions to Focus on Investment
item.description: The U.S. president whitewashed the Saudi crown prince’s poor human rights record while giving him a red-carpet welcome.

item.title: Trump Hosts Mohammed bin Salman to Discuss Investment, F-35 Deals
item.description: The U.S. president whitewashed the Saudi crown prince’s poor human rights record while giving him a red-carpet welcome.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s big MAGA break up
item.description: Defying the president over the Epstein files is her latest bust-up with the Republican Party

item.title: Techno-optimism Can’t Save Us From Climate Change
item.description: Hoping blindly for a technological solution for climate change that may never come is no solution.

item.title: Did China Really Launch the World’s First AI-Based Cyberattacks?
item.description: AI lab Anthropic claimed that Chinese-backed bots are conducting cyber espionage. Experts have questions.

item.title: Geothermal’s time has finally come
item.description: This source of energy could become bigger than nuclear

item.title: China and Japan are in a vicious game of chicken over Taiwan
item.description: Neither side sees backing down as an option

item.title: Restoring Europe’s Social Contracts
item.description: Since World War II, liberal democracies have built and sustained their social contracts on three mutually reinforcing pillars: freedom, prosperity, and the rule of law. If Europe is to thrive in the 21st century and continue to serve as a model of democratic values, it must reinvigorate all three.

item.title: Understanding China’s Overreaction to Takaichi’s Taiwan Comments
item.description: Beijing’s response appeared entirely out of proportion – and that fits with a larger pattern in China-Japan relations.

item.title: Trump Continues to Commit Murder in the Caribbean
item.description: Invoking “non-international armed conflict” does not justify the administration’s drone killings.

item.title: Can ASEAN secure a quantum future?
item.description: To harness the power of quantum, Southeast Asia must upskill, innovate, and think beyond the vendor-supplier model.

item.title: Central Asia Chooses Consolidation Over Integration
item.description: Regional integration may become a matter for a future agenda, but the recent summit showcased a focus on cooperation and consolidation instead.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Interest-Rate Trap
item.description: The Central Bank of Sri Lanka has inexplicably maintained high interest rates in a deflationary environment, which increases debt-service costs and suppresses economic activity. It must change course now, because austerity in the name of fiscal sustainability is self-defeating if it destroys the conditions for growth.

item.title: Asia’s Women on the Frontlines of Climate Change
item.description: "Despite its importance, women’s work is frequently undervalued and rendered invisible by government, private sector and donor-driven programs."

item.title: Palau’s President Pushes for Stronger Climate Action After New Zealand Weakens Methane Targets
item.description: For Palau and other Pacific Island nations, shifts in climate ambition by larger emitters raise concerns about global progress.

item.title: North Korea Denounces South Korea-US Joint Fact Sheet
item.description: After Washington confirmed its support to Seoul’s development of an indigenous nuclear-powered submarine, Pyongyang released a statement criticizing the move.

item.title: India’s Exercise Trishul: Why Pakistan Should Be Worried
item.description: The Indian military has carried out several large-scale tri-service drills over the years, but the recent Trishul exercise was unique.

item.title: Cuba is heading for disaster, unless its regime changes drastically
item.description: An upheaval beckons in an increasingly miserable country

item.title: Four charts show how much money China lends to the rich world
item.description: Many of the loans look harmless. But some are raising eyebrows

item.title: The Illiberal World Order Is Here
item.description: Now that Donald Trump's administration has explicitly rejected the international rules-based institutions and arrangements that America created after World War II, the very idea of an international order is no longer relevant. The world now belongs to illiberal regimes intent on pursuing their own interests.

item.title: The G20 Can No Longer Postpone Debt Relief
item.description: The idea that Africa can finance the green transition while simultaneously spending huge sums on debt service is absurd. That is why the upcoming G20 summit in Johannesburg must end with a commitment to restructuring the liabilities of highly indebted countries, most of which are on the continent.

item.title: How Trump-Era Diplomacy Is Rewriting the Indo-Pacific Playbook
item.description: Sovereignty first, development second.

item.title: Japan’s Stalled Immigration Experiment
item.description: The uncertain future of a promising approach.

item.title: What If ‘America First’ Appears to Work?
item.description: “Might makes right” is still wrong for America, but opposing it just got harder.

item.title: Saudi Arabia is in no hurry to join the Abraham accords
item.description: Muhammad bin Salman no longer needs to recognise Israel to woo America

item.title: Europe Is Selling Ukraine a Pipe Dream
item.description: The EU’s promises of future membership are distracting from Ukraine’s more pressing needs today.

item.title: China and India Are Trapped in a Loop
item.description: Breaking out of their cycle of hope and distrust requires political imagination on both sides.

item.title: The AI Bubble’s Shaky Math
item.description: Today’s massive and still-growing investments in AI and its accompanying infrastructure could well pay off like the internet did, following the investment boom of the late 1990s. But, for now, the gains from AI look more muted, and the macro downsides larger, than in the case of the dot-com bubble.

item.title: India Quietly Exited Military Base in Tajikistan After Lease Lapsed
item.description: Given New Delhi’s limited defense budget, can India make do with logistical hubs and listening posts abroad rather than spending on a full-scale base?

item.title: Why the Thai-Cambodia Peace Deal Is in Tatters
item.description: Land mines, and who planted them, have been an ongoing factor.

item.title: BRICS Is Missing Its Chance
item.description: United by Trump’s hostility, but too divided to seize the moment.

item.title: Philippines Hoping to Conclude South China Sea Code of Conduct in 2026
item.description: It remains to be seen whether ASEAN and China can finalize the long-awaited agreement by the previously agreed deadline of July 2026.
